div.p: Greetings. Yesterday evening I received your letters, brother, and those of the most honorable lord ambassador; but I solemnly assure you that, due to business, I have not yet been able to read those lengthy letters of his.
But as soon as I can free myself a little, I will read them most diligently. Meanwhile, however, while I am busy, I have handed them over to my Gwalther to read.

Therefore, I earnestly beg you to excuse me to the most honorable man for not replying; I will write when the opportunity arises, and indeed as soon as I can. I have nothing to respond to your letters.

Hannibal's expedition is proceeding slowly, and some think it will not proceed at all; for the German princes do not want their men to serve under foreign leaders; and the Emperor has forbidden his men to serve any foreign prince by imperial command.
It is said, therefore, that they are rushing to the Emperor by arranged horses to obtain permission to withdraw the troops; however, rumor has it that the Emperor died this month.
If this is true, many and various disturbances are feared by many, perhaps many disturbances of some will also be dissipated.
[Our Confederates] do not cease to be, as they have been for many years, intolerably insolent. May the Lord restrain all those who desire war and console the afflicted.
All of mine greet you; greet the most honorable lord ambassador, the consuls, Gallicius, Pontasella, etc.
To the most excellent man, Lord Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the Church of Chur, my esteemed lord and dearest brother. Chur.
